title: William Watson: Canada doesn't need more Rube Goldberg growth plans
text:
Andy Blatchford of The Canadian Press reports (“Business leaders bemoan lack of economic plan,” Oct. 28) that some of the country’s business leaders want Canada’s “newly-elected lawmakers to shift their attention to the economy following an election campaign that sorely lacked a critical conversation: how to secure the country’s future prosperity.”

He quotes three business leaders, who are in fact leaders of various business councils, associations and alliances rather than actual businesses, who want governments to get behind innovators, manufacturers and exporters. They all bemoan (the headline writer got that right) the lack of discussion of these subjects in the federal election campaign.

The business leaders evidently feel what the campaign lacked was a Sen. Elizabeth Warren, who has a plan for this, a plan for that, a plan for everything (except, it turns out, financing her biggest spending project of all, universal medicare). What we apparently need as a country is a plan for economic growth and prosperity.

Well, maybe.

Despite Sen. Warren, a plan is a good thing to have only if it’s a good plan. Rube Goldberg had lots and lots of plans, but none you’d actually want. For the benefit of younger readers, Rube Goldberg (1883-1970) was a trained engineer who became a successful American cartoonist, producing innumerable drawings of extremely complicated machines designed to accomplish extremely simple tasks. An example is 1931’s “Self-operating napkin.” Reproduced on a U.S. postage stamp in Goldberg’s honour, it depicts a machine that uses levers, ladles, clocks, parrots, and even small rockets to enable a person to wipe soup from his moustache.

When you see one of these Rube Goldberg machines, government may actually be what comes to mind. Anyone who has done work for a government will have been impressed by the paperwork required to move a cheque from it to you — much more than the private sector ever requires. People seeking government finance for projects speak of the many levels of approval they must obtain.

Despite the bemoaners, it’s wrong to suggest we don’t have an economic plan. The 2017 federal budget — how quickly we forget! — had a big section on securing economic growth. My favourite sentence from it was almost an homage to Rube Goldberg: “The Government of Canada’s vast array of innovation programs makes it difficult for businesses to find and secure the support they need.” Yes, its “vast array!” We are so helpful you can’t get any help from us.

The 2018 budget followed up dramatically. One passage included the number “92” printed in very large font. It turns out 92 is — or was — the number of federal programs already aimed at encouraging innovation. Ninety-two! The budget promised a two-thirds reduction to consolidate these 92 into “35+” programs — so businesses could have 35-stop shopping. I guess that’s better than 92-stop shopping. But not much. Maybe they should ask Amazon in and have Jeff Bezos’ people turn it all into a handy search engine that would automatically pull up the federal program that exactly meets your business’ needs.

The 2018 budget did not make clear, by the way, whether the 92 included the several new initiatives the 2017 budget had introduced, such as the Advisory Council on Economic Growth, Innovation Canada (a new policy “platform”), the Strategic Innovation Fund, the Venture Capital Canada Fund, and a supposedly private but certain to be manipulated Canadian Business Growth Fund, together with six “Economic Strategy Tables” — yes, tables were on the table — designed to set “ambitious growth targets for Canadian innovators.” The 2017 budget also set official Soviet-style numerical targets for exports and high-growth small firms.

Have the bemoaning business leaders forgotten all this? If Maxime Bernier were Liberal leader, he would probably tell them: “Look, we addressed all this. What more do you want?” Of course, if Maxime Bernier were Liberal leader, he’d only ask “What more do you want?”

Productivity, the key to prosperity, isn’t actually that hard an idea. You do more with the same resources. Or do the same with fewer resources. How? I haven’t a clue. You’re the person who knows — or should know — how your enterprise works. It’s very hard for anyone else, least of all government, to develop “knowledge of the particular circumstances of (your) time and place,” to use Ludwig von Mises’ famous summary of what a free economy generates and makes use of. Figuring out exactly how you raise the ratio of output to resources won’t necessarily be easy, though in some circumstances it won’t actually be that hard.

How to encourage productivity? One general rule is to minimize the number of people who aren’t contributing to the mission. (Does that sound like government?) Another is to reward it.

If you’re a business and you raise your productivity, your profits should go up. So what do we do? We tax profits. Not even Rube Goldberg could make that work.

Financial Post
description: The Government of Canada is so helpful you can’t get any help from it
